title: What is Yoga - Definition and Etymology
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Yoga is an invaluable gift of ancient Indian tradition. It is essentially a spiritual discipline based on an extremely subtle science which focuses on bringing harmony between mind and body. It is an art and science for healthy living. The word 'Yoga' is derived from the Sanskrit root 'yuj' meaning 'to join', 'to yoke' or 'to unite'. According to Yogic scriptures, the practice of Yoga leads to the union of individual consciousness with universal consciousness. One who experiences this oneness of existence is said to be 'in Yoga' and is termed as a yogi who has attained a state of freedom, referred to as mukti, nirvāna, kaivalya or moksha.
benefits: Embodies unity of mind and body. Promotes harmony between thought and action. Creates restraint and fulfillment. Establishes harmony between man and nature. Provides holistic approach to health and well-being. Leads to discovery of oneness with ourselves, the world and Nature. Helps overcome all kinds of sufferings. Leads to sense of freedom in every walk of life with holistic health, happiness and harmony.
precautions: Yoga is not a substitute for medical advice. Consult healthcare provider before practicing if you have any medical conditions. Practice under guidance of qualified teacher, especially as beginner.

title: History and Development of Yoga
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: The science of Yoga has its origin thousands of years ago, long before the first religion or belief systems were born. According to Yogic lore, Shiva is seen as the first yogi (ādiyogi) and the first guru (ādiguru). Several thousand years ago, on the banks of lake Kantisarovar in the Himalayas, ādiyogi poured his profound knowledge into the legendary saptarishis or 'seven sages'. Yoga is widely considered as an immortal cultural outcome of the Indus Saraswati Valley Civilisation dating back to 2700 BC. Though Yoga was being practiced in the pre-Vedic period, the great sage Maharishi Patanjali systematised and codified the then existing Yogic practices through Patanjali's Yoga Sutras.
benefits: Rich historical tradition spanning over 4700 years. Global spread through teachings of eminent masters. Prevention of disease and promotion of health. Management of lifestyle-related disorders. Millions of practitioners worldwide benefiting from practice.
precautions: Practice authentic yoga from qualified teachers. Be aware of historical context and traditional practices.

title: Four Fundamental Paths of Yoga
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Yoga works on the level of one's body, mind, emotion and energy. This has given rise to four broad classifications: Karma Yoga where we utilise the body; Jnāna Yoga where we utilise the mind; Bhakti Yoga where we utilise the emotion; and Kriya Yoga where we utilise the energy. Each system of Yoga we practice falls within the gamut of one or more of these categories. Every individual is a unique combination of these four factors. Only a guru (teacher) can advocate the appropriate combination of the four fundamental paths as is necessary for each seeker.
benefits: Comprehensive approach addressing all aspects of being. Personalized path suited to individual constitution. Holistic development of body, mind, emotion and energy. Balanced spiritual growth.
precautions: Essential to work under direction of a qualified guru. Individual assessment needed for appropriate path. Avoid rigid adherence to single path without guidance.

title: Eight Limbs of Yoga - Ashtanga Yoga
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: The widely practiced Yoga sadhanas include: Yama (restraints), Niyama (observances), Āsana (postures), Prānāyāma (breath control), Pratyāhara (sense withdrawal), Dhārana (concentration), Dhyāna (meditation), and Samādhi (integration/absorption). Yamas and Niyamas are considered pre-requisites for further Yogic practices. Āsanas bring about stability of body and mind. Prānāyāma consists of developing awareness and regulation of respiration. Pratyāhara is withdrawal from sense organs. Dhārana is concentration. Dhyāna is meditation and contemplation. Samādhi is complete integration.
benefits: Complete systematic approach to yoga. Progressive development from ethics to enlightenment. Stable body and mind through asanas. Mind control through pranayama. Inner awareness through pratyahara. Enhanced concentration through dharana. Deep meditation through dhyana. Ultimate freedom through samadhi.
precautions: Practice eight limbs systematically under guidance. Don't skip ethical foundations (Yama/Niyama). Build strong asana foundation before advanced practices. Pranayama requires proper instruction.

title: General Guidelines - Before Practice
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Śauca (cleanliness) is an important prerequisite - includes cleanliness of surroundings, body and mind. Practice in calm and quiet atmosphere with relaxed body and mind. Practice on empty stomach or light stomach. Consume small amount of honey in lukewarm water if feeling weak. Bladder and bowels should be empty before starting. Use mattress, Yoga mat, durrie or folded blanket. Wear light and comfortable cotton clothes to facilitate easy movement. Do not perform in state of exhaustion, illness, hurry or acute stress. In case of chronic disease, pain, cardiac problems, consult physician or Yoga therapist before practicing. Consult experts before practicing during pregnancy and menstruation.
benefits: Safe and effective practice. Maximum benefits from session. Prevents injury and discomfort. Creates conducive environment for practice. Proper preparation of body and mind.
precautions: Contraindications: Exhaustion, illness, hurry, acute stress. Mandatory medical consultation for: chronic disease, pain, cardiac problems, pregnancy, menstruation. Never practice on full stomach. Ensure clean, quiet environment.

title: General Guidelines - During Practice
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Start with prayer or invocation to create conducive environment and relax mind. Perform slowly, in relaxed manner, with awareness of body and breath. Do not hold breath unless specially mentioned. Breathing should always be through nostrils unless instructed otherwise. Do not hold body tightly or jerk the body. Perform according to your own capacity. Takes time to get good results - persistent and regular practice is essential. Be aware of contra-indications and limitations for each practice. Session should end with meditation, deep silence or Śhānti paṭha (peace chant).
benefits: Safe practice with body awareness. Proper breathing patterns. Prevention of injury. Gradual progress at own pace. Mental relaxation and focus. Integration of practice benefits.
precautions: Never force or strain. Respect body's current capacity. Maintain breath awareness throughout. Follow specific contraindications for each pose. End practice properly for integration.

title: General Guidelines - After Practice
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Bath may be taken only after 20-30 minutes of practice. Food may be consumed only after 20-30 minutes of practice. This allows body to settle and normalize after practice. For dietary guidelines: vegetarian diet is usually recommended. For persons over 30 years, two meals a day should suffice, except in cases of illness or very high physical activity or labour.
benefits: Proper integration of practice effects. Body temperature normalization. Energy settling. Optimal digestion. Enhanced practice benefits through proper timing.
precautions: Wait 20-30 minutes before bathing. Wait 20-30 minutes before eating. Avoid rushing after practice. Allow body time to adjust.

title: How Yoga Can Help - Health Benefits
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Medical research has uncovered many physical and mental benefits that Yoga offers. Yoga is beneficial for physical fitness, musculoskeletal functioning and cardio-vascular health. Beneficial in management of diabetes, respiratory disorders, hypertension, hypotension and many lifestyle-related disorders. Helps to reduce depression, fatigue, anxiety disorders and stress. Regulates menopausal symptoms. In essence, Yoga is a process of creating a body and mind that are stepping-stones, not hurdles, to an exuberant and fulfilling life.
benefits: Physical fitness improvement. Enhanced musculoskeletal function. Cardiovascular health. Diabetes management. Respiratory disorder relief. Blood pressure regulation. Reduced depression and anxiety. Stress relief. Fatigue reduction. Menopausal symptom regulation. Disease prevention. Health promotion. Lifestyle disorder management.
precautions: Yoga complements but doesn't replace medical treatment. Consult healthcare provider for serious conditions. Practice appropriately for specific health issues.

title: Opening Prayer - Saṃgacchadhvam
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Rigveda 10.191.2
info: Yogic Practice shall start with a prayer or prayerful mood to enhance benefits of practice. Sanskrit: Saṃgacchadhvaṃ saṃvadadhvaṃ saṃ vo manāṃsi jānatām, devā bhāgaṃ yathā pūrve sañjānānā upāsate. Translation: May you move in harmony; may you speak in unison; let our mind be equanimous like in the beginning; let the divinity manifest in your sacred endeavours.
benefits: Creates conducive environment to relax mind. Sets intention for practice. Establishes mental calm. Connects to tradition. Invokes divine blessings. Promotes harmony and unity. Prepares mind for deeper practice.
precautions: None. Prayer is optional but recommended. Can be recited mentally or aloud. Respect the sacred intention.

title: Neck Bending - Griva Sanchalan
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Starting Position: Samasthiti (feet comfortably apart, hands beside body). Stage 1 - Forward/Backward: Exhale and move head forward touching chin to chest. Inhale and move head back comfortably. Repeat 2 rounds. Stage 2 - Right/Left Bending: Exhale and bend head to right bringing ear toward shoulder without raising shoulder. Inhale return to normal. Repeat other side. 2 rounds each. Stage 3 - Right/Left Twisting: Exhale and turn head right bringing chin in line with shoulder. Inhale return. Repeat left. 2 rounds. Stage 4 - Neck Rotation: Exhale bend head forward. Inhale and rotate head clockwise in full circular motion. Repeat anti-clockwise. 2 rounds each direction.
benefits: Loosens neck joints and muscles. Relieves tension from poor posture. Increases microcirculation. Improves neck flexibility and range of motion. Reduces stiffness. Prepares for asana practice.
precautions: Contraindications: Cervical spondylitis, high blood pressure, vertigo (elderly should avoid). Move only as far as comfortable without overstrain. Keep shoulders relaxed and steady. Can be practiced sitting in chair. People with neck pain should practice gently, especially when taking head back.

title: Trunk Twisting - Katishakti Vikasak
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Starting Position: Samasthiti with legs 2-3 feet apart. Rise both arms to chest level with palms facing each other, parallel. Exhale and twist body to left so right palm touches left shoulder. Inhale return to center. Exhale twist right so left palm touches right shoulder. Inhale return. This is one round - repeat two more times. Relax in Samasthiti.
benefits: Improves spine flexibility. Loosens trunk muscles. Increases microcirculation. Prepares spine for twisting asanas. Massages abdominal organs. Reduces waist fat.
precautions: Contraindications: Severe back pain, vertebral and disc disorders, after abdominal surgery, during menstruation. Do slowly with breathing coordination. Cardiac patients shall do with care.

title: Knee Movement - Knee Bending
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Starting Position: Samasthiti. Inhale and lift arms to shoulder level, palms facing down. Exhale and bend knees bringing body to squatting position. In final position both arms and thighs should be parallel to ground. Inhale and straighten body. Exhale while bringing hands down. Repeat two more times.
benefits: Strengthens knee joints and hip joints. Improves lower body strength. Increases leg flexibility. Prepares legs for standing asanas. Enhances balance.
precautions: Contraindications: Acute arthritis conditions. Avoid if experiencing knee pain. Don't bend beyond comfortable range. Keep knees aligned over toes.

title: Tādāsana - Palm Tree Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Tāda means palm tree or mountain. This asana teaches attaining stability and firmness and forms base for all standing asanas. Stand with feet 2 inches apart. Interlock fingers and turn wrists outward. Inhale, raise arms up in line with shoulders. Raise heels off floor and balance on toes. Stay 10-15 seconds. Exhale, bring heels down. Release interlock and bring arms down parallel to trunk. Return to standing posture.
benefits: Brings stability in body. Clears up congestion of spinal nerves. Corrects faulty posture. Helps increase height up to certain age. Improves balance and concentration. Strengthens legs and ankles. Stretches entire body. Develops body awareness.
precautions: Contraindications: Acute cardiac problems, varicose veins, vertigo. Avoid lifting toes in these conditions. Practice near wall for balance support if needed.

title: Vṛikṣāsana - Tree Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Vṛkṣa means tree. Final position resembles shape of tree. Stand with feet 2 inches apart. Focus on point in front. Exhale, bend right leg and place foot on inside of left thigh with heel touching perineum. Inhale and extend arms up joining palms. Stay in position 10-30 seconds breathing normally. Exhale and bring arms and right foot down. Relax and repeat with left leg.
benefits: Improves neuro-muscular coordination, balance, endurance and alertness. Tones up leg muscles. Rejuvenates ligaments. Develops concentration and focus. Strengthens ankles and improves posture. Calms mind.
precautions: Contraindications: Arthritis, vertigo, obesity. Avoid if experiencing these conditions. Never place foot directly on knee joint. Use wall for support if balance is difficult. Can place foot on calf or ankle if thigh placement too challenging.

title: Pāda-Hastāsana - Hands to Feet Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Pāda means feet, hasta means hands. Also called Uttānāsana. Stand straight with feet 2 inches apart. Inhale slowly and raise arms up. Stretch body from waist. Exhale and bend forward until trunk is parallel to ground. Exhale and bend forward until entire palm rests on ground. Maintain final posture 10-30 seconds. Those with stiff back should bend according to capacity. Inhale, come up slowly to vertical and stretch arms above head. Exhale and return to starting position in reverse order. Relax in Tādāsana.
benefits: Makes spine flexible. Improves digestion. Prevents constipation and menstrual problems. Stretches hamstrings and back. Increases blood flow to brain. Calms nervous system. Reduces abdominal fat.
precautions: Contraindications: Cardiac or back problems, abdominal inflammation, hernia, ulcers, high myopia, vertigo, pregnancy, vertebral and disc disorders. Avoid in all these conditions. Bend only to comfortable capacity - never force. Keep knees slightly bent if hamstrings tight.

title: Ardha Cạkrāsana - Half Wheel Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Ardha means half, Cạkra means wheel. Body takes shape of half wheel. Support back at waist with fingers together pointing forward or downward. Drop head backwards stretching neck muscles. Inhale and bend backwards from lumbar region. Exhale and relax. Stay 10-30 seconds with normal breathing. Inhale and slowly come up.
benefits: Makes spine flexible. Strengthens spinal nerves. Strengthens neck muscles. Improves breathing capacity. Helps in cervical spondylitis. Opens chest and shoulders. Improves posture.
precautions: Contraindications: Vertigo or tendency to giddiness. Hypertensive patients shall bend with care and minimally. Never force backward bend. Support lower back with hands throughout. Start with small range and gradually increase.

title: Trikoṇāsana - Triangle Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Trikoṇa means triangle. Tri means three and kona is angle. Asana resembles three triangles made by trunk and limbs. Stand with feet comfortably apart. Slowly raise both arms sideways till horizontal. Exhale, slowly bend to right and place right hand behind right foot. Left arm straight up in line with right arm. Turn left palm forward. Turn head and gaze at tip of left middle finger. Remain 10-30 seconds with normal breathing. Inhale slowly come up. Repeat for left side.
benefits: Prevents flat foot. Strengthens calf, thigh and waist muscles. Makes spine flexible. Improves lung capacity. Tones abdominal organs. Enhances balance and stability. Stretches hips and hamstrings.
precautions: Contraindications: Slipped disc, sciatica, after abdominal surgery. Do not overdo lateral stretch beyond limits. If cannot touch feet, reach for knees instead. Those with neck problems should look forward instead of up.

title: Bhadrāsana - Firm/Auspicious Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Hathapradipika
info: Bhadra means firm or auspicious. Starting: Long sitting posture (Viṣrāmāsana). Sit erect with legs stretched straight in front. Keep hands beside hips - this is Dandāsana. Put soles of feet together. Exhale and clasp hands together over toes. Pull heels as close as possible to perineum region. If thighs not touching floor, place soft cushion under knees for support. This is final position. Stay for some time.
benefits: Keeps body firm and stabilizes mind. Keeps knees and hip joints healthy. Helps relieve knee pain. Acts on abdominal organs and releases abdominal tension. Benefits women by relieving abdominal pain during menstruation. Opens hips. Improves flexibility.
precautions: Contraindications: Severe arthritis, sciatica. Avoid in these conditions. Don't force knees down. Use props for support if needed. Practice gently and progressively.

title: Ardha Uṣṭrāsana - Half Camel Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Uṣṭra means camel. Final version resembles hump of camel. This is half (ardha) version. From Viṣrāmāsana come to Dandāsana. Fold legs and sit on heels with thighs close and big toes touching. Place hands on knees. Head and back straight - this is Vajrāsana. Stand on knees. Place hands on waist with fingers pointing downward. Keep elbows and shoulders parallel. Bend head back and stretch neck muscles. Inhale and bend trunk backwards as much as possible. Exhale and relax. Keep thighs perpendicular to ground. Remain 10-30 seconds with normal breathing. Return with inhalation, sit in Vajrāsana. Relax in Viṣrāmāsana. Note: If can reach heels, place hands on them and bend backwards - this is Uṣṭrāsana.
benefits: Relieves constipation and back pain. Increases blood circulation to head and cardiac region. Opens chest and throat. Improves spinal flexibility. Stimulates digestive organs. Stretches hip flexors and quadriceps.
precautions: Contraindications: Hernia, abdominal injuries, arthritis, vertigo, pregnancy. Avoid in all these conditions. Never force into full backbend. Progress gradually. Keep thighs perpendicular to prevent strain.

title: Śaśānkāsana - Hare Posture (Child's Pose)
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Gheranda Samhita
info: Śaśaṇka means hare. Starting: Vajrāsana. Spread both knees wide apart keeping big toes touching. Keep palms between knees. Exhale and slowly stretch them full length. Bend forward and place chin on ground. Keep arms parallel. Look in front and maintain posture. Inhale and come up. Exhale and come back to Vajrāsana. Stretch legs back to Viṣrāmāsana.
benefits: Helps reduce stress and anger. Tones up reproductive organs. Relieves constipation. Improves digestion. Relieves back pain. Calms nervous system. Massages internal organs. Promotes relaxation. Stretches spine gently.
precautions: Contraindications: Acute backache. Patients with osteoarthritis of knees should exercise with caution or avoid Vajrāsana positions. Pregnant women should keep knees wide apart. Can use blanket under knees for comfort.

title: Vakrāsana - Spinal Twist Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Vakra means twisted. Spine is twisted which has rejuvenating effect on functioning. Starting: Dandāsana. Bend right leg and place right foot beside left knee. Exhale and twist body to right. Bring left arm around right knee and clasp right big toe or place palm beside right foot. Take right arm back and keep palm on ground with back straight. Remain 10-30 seconds with normal breathing and relax. Release hands with exhalation and relax. Repeat same on other side.
benefits: Increases flexibility of spine. Helps overcome constipation and dyspepsia. Stimulates pancreas and helps in management of diabetes. Massages abdominal organs. Improves digestion. Detoxifies spine. Energizes nervous system. Tones kidneys and liver.
precautions: Contraindications: Severe back pain, vertebral and disc disorders, after abdominal surgery, during menstruation. Avoid in these conditions. Never force twist. Twist from belly, not shoulders. Keep spine elongated throughout.

title: Bhujangāsana - Cobra Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Gheranda Samhita
info: Bhujanga means snake or cobra. Body is raised like hood of snake. Starting: Prone posture or Makarāsana. Lie on stomach, rest head on hands and relax body. Join legs and stretch arms. Keep forehead on ground. Place hands beside body with palms and elbows on ground. Inhale slowly, lift chin and chest up to navel region. Stay comfortably - this is Sarala Bhujangāsana. Come back, place forehead on ground. Keep palms besides chest where elbows were and raise elbows. Inhale, slowly lift chin and chest up to navel region - this is Bhujangāsana. Exhale, rest forehead on ground, place palms and rest head on palms, spread legs and relax. Keep legs firm so no load on lumbar spine.
benefits: Best for stress management. Reduces abdominal fat. Alleviates constipation. Helps remove backache and bronchial problems. Strengthens spine and back muscles. Opens chest improving breathing. Stimulates abdominal organs. Improves blood circulation to spine. Therapeutic for asthma.
precautions: Contraindications: Abdominal surgery (avoid 2-3 months after), hernia, ulcers, hyperthyroid, pregnancy, serious back injury, carpal tunnel. Never push heavily with arms - lift comes from back strength. Keep elbows slightly bent. Don't strain neck by looking too far up.

title: Śalabhāsana - Locust Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Gheranda Samhita
info: Śalabha means locust. Starting: Prone posture, Makarāsana. Lie on stomach in Makarāsana. Rest chin on floor. Keep both hands beside body, palms facing upwards. Inhale, raise legs off floor as much as possible without bending knees. Extend arms and legs well to ease lift of body off floor. Stay 10-20 seconds breathing normally. Exhale, bring legs down toward floor. Rest few seconds in Makarāsana. Pull up knee caps and squeeze buttocks to improve posture. More beneficial when performed after Bhujangāsana.
benefits: Helps in sciatica and lower backache. Tones hip muscles and kidney region. Reduces fat on thighs and buttocks. Good for weight management. Helps abdominal organs aiding digestion. Strengthens entire back, hips and legs. Improves lung capacity. Corrects postural defects.
precautions: Contraindications: Cardiac problems, severe lower back pain, high blood pressure, peptic ulcers, hernia, pregnancy. Avoid in all these conditions. Proceed cautiously if any back issues. Never jerk while lifting. Lift should be smooth and controlled.

title: Makarāsana - Crocodile Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Makara means crocodile. Body resembles crocodile. Starting: Prone relaxation posture. Lie on stomach with feet wide apart, feet pointing outward. Bend both arms and place right hand on left hand. Place forehead on hands. Keep eyes closed. This is Makarāsana. This asana is practiced for relaxation in all prone postures.
benefits: Promotes relaxation of lower back. Helps in recovery of back problems. Indicated for all orthopedic ailments. Indicated to counter stress and anxiety. Allows spine to rest. Releases tension in shoulders and neck. Calms nervous system. Provides break between challenging prone poses.
precautions: Contraindications: Low blood pressure, severe cardiac problems, pregnancy (especially later stages). Generally very safe relaxation pose. Adjust arm position for comfort. Can turn head to either side if more comfortable.

title: Śetubandhāsana - Bridge Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Yogarahasya
info: Setubandha means formation of bridge. Body is positioned like bridge. Also called Catuṣpādāsana. Starting: Supine lying, Śavāsana. Bend both legs at knees and bring heels near buttocks. Hold both ankles firmly. Keep knees and feet in one straight line. Inhale, slowly raise buttocks and trunk up as much as possible to form bridge. Remain 10-30 seconds with normal breathing. Exhale, slowly return to original position and relax in Śavāsana. In final position shoulders and head remain in contact with floor. If required, can support body at waist with hands in final position.
benefits: Relieves depression and anxiety. Strengthens lower back muscles. Stretches abdominal organs, improves digestion and helps relieve constipation. Stretches chest, neck and spine. Stimulates thyroid and abdominal organs. Calms brain. Therapeutic for asthma, high blood pressure, osteoporosis. Relieves menstrual discomfort.
precautions: Contraindications: Ulcers, hernia, advanced pregnancy, neck injury. In final position shoulders and head should remain on floor. Never force lift. Can use block under sacrum for supported version.

title: Pavanamuktāsana - Wind Releasing Posture
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Shri Yoga Kaustubha
info: Pavan means wind, mukta means release or make free. Asana useful in removing wind or flatulence from stomach and intestines. Starting: Śavāsana. Lie flat on back. Bend both knees and bring thighs to chest. Interlock fingers and clasp shin below knees. Exhale, raise head till chin touches knees and relax - this is Pavanamuktāsana. Bring head back to ground. While exhaling, lower legs to floor. Rest in Śavāsana. Synchronize breathing with leg movement. While touching knee with nose/forehead, should feel lumbar region stretch. Keep eyes closed and focus attention on lumbar region.
benefits: Removes constipation. Gives relief from flatulence. Decreases bloating sensation in abdomen and aids digestion. Offers deep internal pressure, massage and stretching of muscles, ligaments and tendons in pelvis and waist region. Tones up back muscles and spinal nerves. Massages abdominal organs. Strengthens arms and legs.
precautions: Contraindications: Abdominal injuries, hernia, sciatica, severe back pain, pregnancy, slipped disc. Avoid in all these conditions. Never force chin to knees. Practice gently with awareness of lumbar region.

title: Śavāsana - Corpse Posture (Deep Relaxation)
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Gheranda Samhita
info: Sava means dead body. Final position resembles dead body. Starting: Supine Relaxation Posture. Lie on back with arms and legs comfortably apart. Palms facing upward, eyes closed. Relax whole body consciously. Become aware of natural breath and allow it to become rhythmic and slow. Remain in position till feeling refreshed and relaxed.
benefits: Helps relieve all kinds of tensions and gives rest to both body and mind. Relaxes whole psycho-physiological system. Mind which is constantly attracted to outer world takes U-turn and moves inwards, gradually getting absorbed. As mind turns quiet and absorbed, practitioner remains undisturbed by external environment. Very beneficial in management of stress and its consequences. Reduces blood pressure and heart rate. Promotes deep rest. Allows integration of practice benefits. Essential final relaxation.
precautions: Generally safe for everyone. Stay warm with blanket if needed. Some people fall asleep - this is okay but try to maintain awareness. Most important pose despite appearing simple. Pregnant women can lie on left side. Those with back issues can bend knees, feet flat on floor.

title: Kapālabhāti - Skull Shining Breath
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Gheranda Samhita
info: Starting: Any meditative posture (Sukāsana/Padmāsana/Vajrāsana). Sit in meditative posture. Close eyes and relax whole body. Inhale deeply through both nostrils, expand chest. Expel breath with forceful contractions of abdominal muscles and relax. Do not strain. Continue active/forceful exhalation and passive inhalation. Complete 30 rapid breaths, then take deep breath and exhale slowly - this is one round. Each round followed by deep breathing. Repeat 2 more rounds. Breathing: Forceful exhalation by contracting abdominal muscles without undue movements in chest and shoulder. Inhalation passive throughout. Beginners practice up to 3 rounds of 20 breaths each. Count and rounds increased gradually over time.
benefits: Purifies frontal air sinuses. Helps overcome cough disorders. Useful in treating cold, rhinitis, sinusitis, asthma and bronchial infections. Rejuvenates whole body. Keeps face young and vibrant. Balances and strengthens nervous system. Tones up digestive system. Cleanses respiratory system. Energizes body and mind. Increases oxygen to brain. Improves concentration.
precautions: Contraindications: Cardiac conditions, giddiness, high blood pressure, vertigo, chronic nose bleeding, epilepsy, migraine, stroke, hernia, gastric ulcers, pregnancy, menstruation, recent abdominal surgery. Avoid in all these conditions. Stop if feeling dizzy. Heating practice - best in morning. Never strain or force.

title: Nādiśodhana/Anuloma Viloma - Alternate Nostril Breathing
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Hathapradipika
info: Main characteristic is alternate breathing through left and right nostrils without or with retention (kumbhaka). Starting: Any meditative posture. Keep spine and head straight with eyes closed. Relax body with few deep breaths. Keep left palm on left knee in Jnāna mudra. Right hand in Nāsāgra mudra. Place ring and small fingers on left nostril, fold middle and index finger. Place right thumb on right nostril. Breathe in from left nostril. Close left nostril with small and ring fingers, release thumb from right nostril, exhale through right. Next inhale through right nostril. At end of inhalation close right nostril, open left and exhale through it. This complete process is one round. Repeat 5 rounds. Ratio and timing: For beginners duration of inhalation and exhalation should be equal. Gradually make 1:2 (inhalation:exhalation). Breath should be slow, steady and controlled, not forced or restricted.
benefits: Main purpose is to purify principle channels of carrying energy (nadis), hence nourishes whole body. Induces tranquility. Helps improve concentration. Increases vitality. Lowers stress and anxiety levels. Balances left and right brain hemispheres. Calms nervous system. Improves respiratory function. Prepares mind for meditation. One of safest and most beneficial pranayamas.
precautions: Generally very safe for almost everyone. Never force breath. Maintain smooth, comfortable breathing. If feeling lightheaded, return to normal breathing. Practice on empty stomach. Can be practiced daily.

title: Bhrāmarī Prāṇāyāma - Bee Breath
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Hathapradipika
info: Bhrāmarī derived from bhramara meaning black bee. Sound produced resembles buzzing of black bee. Starting: Any meditative posture. Type 1: Sit in meditative posture with eyes closed. Inhale deeply through nose. Exhale slowly in controlled manner while making deep, steady humming sound like black bee. This is one round. Repeat 5 rounds. Type 2: Sit in meditative posture with eyes closed. Inhale deeply through nose. Close eyes with index fingers, mouth with ring and small fingers, ears with thumbs (Śanmukhi Mudra). Exhale slowly in controlled manner while making deep, steady humming sound like black bee. This is one round. Repeat 5 rounds.
benefits: Relieves stress and helps in alleviating anxiety, anger and hyperactivity. Resonance effect of humming sound creates soothing effect on mind and nervous system. Great tranquilizer. Good in management of stress-related disorders. Useful preparatory prāṇāyāma for concentration and meditation. Instantly calms mind. Reduces blood pressure. Improves concentration and memory. Helps insomnia. Therapeutic for thyroid.
precautions: Contraindications: Nose and ear infections. Generally very safe. One of best breathing techniques for calming mind. Can be practiced anytime feeling stressed or anxious.

title: Dhyāna in Śambhavī Mudra - Meditation
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Yoga Sutra of Patanjali
info: Dhyāna or meditation is act of continuous contemplation. Starting: Any meditative posture. Keep spine comfortably erect. Hold Jnāna mudra: Touch tip of thumb to tip of index finger forming circle. Other three fingers straight and relaxed, side-by-side and touching. Keep palms facing upwards upon thighs. Arms and shoulders loose and relaxed. Close eyes and sit with slightly upturned face. Need not concentrate. Just maintain mild focus between eyebrows and be conscious of breath. Dissolve thoughts and attain single and pure thought. Meditate. For beginners soothing music may be played in background. Stay as long as you can.
benefits: Most important component of Yoga practice. Helps practitioner eliminate negative emotions like fear, anger, depression, anxiety and develop positive emotions. Keeps mind calm and quiet. Increases concentration, memory, clarity of thought and will power. Rejuvenates whole body and mind giving proper rest. Leads to self-realization. Reduces stress profoundly. Enhances self-awareness. Improves emotional regulation. Develops witness consciousness.
precautions: No contraindications. Safe for everyone. Start with short duration and gradually increase. Don't force concentration. Allow thoughts to settle naturally. Regular practice more important than long duration. Best practiced daily at same time. Morning ideal but evening also suitable. Consistency key to progress.

title: Sankalpa - Positive Resolve
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: End Yoga Practice Session with Sankalpa. Recommended Sankalpa: I commit to make myself into healthy, peaceful, joyful and loving human being. Through every action of mine, I will strive to create peaceful and loving atmosphere around me. I strive to break limitations of who I am right now and include entire world as my own. I recognize kinship of my own life with every other life. I recognize unity of all there is.
benefits: Plants seeds of positive transformation. Aligns subconscious with conscious goals. Creates profound changes through consistent practice. Embeds practice benefits in daily life. Strengthens resolve and commitment. Promotes universal consciousness and compassion. Extends personal practice to world service.
precautions: State in present tense as if already true. Keep brief and clear. Should be emotionally resonant and personally meaningful. Repeat consistently. Best stated when mind is relaxed after practice. Can create personal sankalpa relevant to individual goals.

title: Śāntih Pātha - Peace Invocation
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India
info: Shanti Patha or Peace Chant concludes yoga practice. Sanskrit: Sarve Bhavantu Sukhinah, Sarve Santu Nirāmayāh. Sarve Bhadrāṇi Paśyantu, Mā kaścit Duḥkha Bhāgbhavet. Om Śāntiḥ Śāntiḥ Śāntiḥ. Translation: May All become Happy, May All be Free from Illness. May All See what is Auspicious, May no one Suffer. Om Peace, Peace, Peace. Three repetitions of Shanti represent: Adhibhautika (peace with external world and beings), Adhidaivika (peace with nature and divine), Adhyatmika (inner peace within oneself).
benefits: Extends wishes of wellbeing to all beings. Embodies yoga's principle that individual wellbeing interconnected with universal wellbeing. Transcends ego boundaries. Aligns with highest yogic ideals of compassion and unity. Cultivates genuine benevolence. Reminds that practice serves collective peace and harmony. Creates positive vibrations. Concludes practice on universal note.
precautions: No contraindications. Can be chanted or repeated silently. Understand and feel the meaning while chanting. Can be chanted in Sanskrit, transliteration, or translation. Intention and feeling most important.

title: Bhastrika Pranayama - Bellows Breath
info: Bhastrika is a powerful energizing breath technique that resembles the bellows of a blacksmith. Sit in a comfortable meditative posture with spine erect. Take a deep inhalation through both nostrils, expanding the chest. Immediately follow with a forceful exhalation through both nostrils. Unlike Kapalabhati, both inhalation and exhalation are active and forceful. The breath should be rapid but rhythmic. Start with 10 breaths per round, gradually increasing to 20-30. Practice 3 rounds with rest between each. The sound should resemble a blacksmith's bellows - strong and steady.
benefits: Powerfully energizes the entire body and mind. Increases metabolic rate and generates internal heat. Strengthens respiratory system and increases lung capacity. Oxygenates blood thoroughly. Clears nasal passages and sinuses. Stimulates digestive fire (Agni). Prepares body and mind for meditation. Balances all three doshas in Ayurveda. Awakens dormant energy and vitality.
precautions: Contraindications: Pregnancy, menstruation, high blood pressure, heart disease, hernia, gastric ulcer, epilepsy, recent abdominal surgery, fever, vertigo, detached retina, glaucoma. Practice only under expert guidance initially. Stop if you feel dizzy, nauseous, or overheated. This is a heating practice - best performed in morning or cool weather.

title: Viloma Pranayama - Interrupted Breath
info: Viloma means 'against the natural order.' This technique involves pausing during inhalation or exhalation. Stage 1 - Interrupted Inhalation: Inhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds with lungs partially full. Continue inhaling in stages until lungs are completely full. Exhale smoothly and completely. Stage 2 - Interrupted Exhalation: Inhale smoothly and completely. Exhale for 2 seconds, pause for 2 seconds with lungs partially empty. Continue exhaling in stages until lungs are completely empty. Practice 5-10 rounds of each stage. This technique requires precise control and awareness of breath.
benefits: Develops exceptional breath control and awareness. Increases lung capacity gradually. Strengthens respiratory muscles. Calms nervous system profoundly. Excellent for anxiety and stress relief. Improves focus and concentration. Prepares for advanced pranayama practices. Helps manage respiratory conditions like asthma when practiced gently.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort. Avoid if you have severe respiratory problems. Never force the breath or create strain. If dizzy, return to normal breathing immediately.

title: Sama Vritti - Equal Breathing (Box Breathing)
info: Sama Vritti means 'equal fluctuation' referring to equal duration for all parts of the breath cycle. Sit comfortably with spine erect. Begin by establishing a natural breath rhythm. Then make inhalation and exhalation equal in length - start with a count of 4. Inhale for 4 counts, exhale for 4 counts. Once comfortable, add retention: Inhale for 4, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold empty for 4. This creates a 'box' pattern. Gradually increase count to 6 or 8 as capacity develops. Maintain smooth, comfortable breathing throughout.
benefits: Creates mental and emotional balance. Reduces anxiety and stress immediately. Improves focus and concentration. Regulates nervous system. Balances left and right brain hemispheres. Prepares mind for meditation. Used by military and first responders for stress management. Improves sleep quality when practiced before bed.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort. If breath retention causes discomfort, practice without holds. Never strain or force the breath. Those with respiratory issues should practice without retention or under supervision.

title: Chandra Bhedana - Left Nostril Breathing (Moon Piercing)
info: Chandra Bhedana is a cooling breath that activates the lunar (Ida) energy channel. Sit in a comfortable meditative posture. Use right hand in Nasagra Mudra. Close right nostril with thumb. Inhale slowly and deeply through left nostril only. At the top of inhalation, close left nostril with ring finger. Exhale through right nostril. This completes one round. Continue for 5-10 minutes. Always inhale through left, exhale through right. The left nostril is associated with cooling, calming energy.
benefits: Cools the body and mind. Reduces excess heat and inflammation. Calms nervous system and reduces stress. Lowers blood pressure. Reduces anger and aggression. Promotes sleep and relaxation. Balances excess Pitta dosha. Useful in hot weather or after heating practices. Soothes headaches and reduces mental agitation.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort. Avoid in very cold weather or if you have a cold. Those with low blood pressure should practice cautiously. Not recommended for those with depression as it may increase lethargy.

title: Surya Bhedana - Right Nostril Breathing (Sun Piercing)
info: Surya Bhedana is a heating breath that activates the solar (Pingala) energy channel. Sit comfortably with spine erect. Use right hand in Nasagra Mudra. Close left nostril with ring finger. Inhale slowly and deeply through right nostril only. At the top of inhalation, close right nostril with thumb. Exhale through left nostril. This completes one round. Continue for 5-10 minutes. Always inhale through right, exhale through left. The right nostril is associated with heating, activating energy.
benefits: Energizes body and mind. Increases digestive fire (Agni). Generates internal heat. Activates sympathetic nervous system appropriately. Useful in cold weather. Helps overcome lethargy and depression. Balances excess Kapha dosha. Improves concentration and alertness. Prepares body for physical activity.
precautions: Contraindications: High blood pressure, heart disease, anxiety disorders, fever, excess heat in body. Avoid in hot weather or if feeling overheated. Not suitable for those with Pitta imbalance. Practice in morning or cool part of day. Stop if feeling agitated or overheated.

title: Dirga Pranayama - Three-Part Breath (Complete Yogic Breath)
info: Dirga Pranayama teaches complete utilization of lung capacity in three parts. Lie down or sit comfortably. Place one hand on belly, one on chest. Part 1 - Abdominal Breathing: Inhale deeply into belly, allowing it to expand. Exhale, drawing belly toward spine. Part 2 - Thoracic Breathing: Inhale into belly, then expand ribs and chest. Exhale from chest, then belly. Part 3 - Clavicular Breathing: Inhale into belly, ribs, then upper chest and collarbones. Exhale from top to bottom. Practice smooth, continuous breath filling all three areas. This is the foundation of all pranayama.
benefits: Maximizes oxygen intake and lung capacity. Reduces stress and anxiety immediately. Improves respiratory function. Massages internal organs through diaphragm movement. Calms nervous system. Excellent for beginners. Prepares for advanced pranayama. Helps manage asthma and breathing difficulties. Improves body awareness.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort. This is very safe for almost everyone. If feeling dizzy, breathe normally and rest. Never force the breath.

title: Utkatasana - Chair Pose (Fierce Pose)
info: Utkatasana builds strength and stamina. Stand in Tadasana with feet hip-width apart. Inhale and raise arms overhead, palms facing each other or joined. Exhale and bend knees as if sitting in an invisible chair. Lower hips until thighs are as close to parallel with floor as possible. Keep weight in heels, knees aligned over ankles (not beyond toes). Engage core and lengthen spine. Gaze forward or slightly up. Hold for 30-60 seconds while breathing steadily. To release, inhale and straighten legs, exhale and lower arms.
benefits: Strengthens thighs, calves, ankles, and spine. Tones shoulders and chest. Stimulates heart and diaphragm. Strengthens core muscles. Improves balance and stability. Builds stamina and willpower. Stretches Achilles tendons. Reduces flat feet. Therapeutic for building overall strength.
precautions: Contraindications: Chronic knee injury, arthritis in knees, headache, low blood pressure. Those with knee problems should not lower as deeply. Keep knees aligned - don't let them collapse inward. If lower back strains, engage core more and don't sit as low.

title: Garudasana - Eagle Pose
info: Garudasana is named after Garuda, the eagle vehicle of Lord Vishnu. Stand in Tadasana. Bend knees slightly. Lift right foot and cross right thigh over left thigh. Hook right foot behind left calf if possible, or rest toes on floor. Extend arms forward, cross left arm over right at elbows. Bend elbows and wrap forearms, bringing palms together (or backs of hands together). Lift elbows to shoulder height, fingers pointing up. Sink deeper into the standing leg. Hold 30-60 seconds. Release and repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Strengthens ankles, calves, thighs, and hips. Opens shoulder joints and upper back. Improves balance and concentration. Stretches outer thighs, hips, shoulders, and upper back. Therapeutic for sciatica and rheumatism. Improves joint flexibility. Develops mental focus and stability.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Contraindications: Knee injury, ankle injury, recent shoulder surgery. Those with knee problems should practice without the foot hook. If balance is challenging, practice near a wall.

title: Natarajasana - Dancer's Pose (Lord of the Dance Pose)
info: Natarajasana is dedicated to Shiva as Nataraja, the cosmic dancer. Stand in Tadasana. Shift weight to left foot. Bend right knee, bringing heel toward buttock. Reach back with right hand and grasp right ankle or foot. Extend left arm forward and up for balance. Begin to kick right foot into hand while hinging forward from hip. Lift right leg as high as comfortable while maintaining balance. Keep standing leg strong and slightly bent. Gaze at a fixed point ahead. Hold 30-60 seconds. Release carefully and repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Strengthens legs, ankles, and core. Opens chest and shoulders. Improves balance and concentration. Stretches thighs, groins, abdomen, chest, and shoulders. Develops grace and poise. Strengthens back muscles. Improves posture. Therapeutic for improving focus and mental clarity.
precautions: Contraindications: Low blood pressure, ankle or knee injury, severe back problems. Practice near a wall for support if needed. Those with balance issues should practice a gentler version. Avoid if you have severe vertigo.

title: Parsvottanasana - Pyramid Pose (Intense Side Stretch)
info: Parsvottanasana provides an intense stretch to the hamstrings and spine. Stand in Tadasana. Step right foot back about 3-4 feet. Turn right foot out 45-60 degrees. Square hips to face forward. Bring hands to prayer position behind back (or hold elbows). Inhale and lengthen spine. Exhale and fold forward from hips over front leg, keeping spine long. Bring torso as close to front thigh as possible. Keep both legs straight. Hold 30-60 seconds breathing steadily. Inhale to rise up. Repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Deeply stretches hamstrings, hips, and spine. Strengthens legs and improves balance. Opens shoulders and chest. Calms the brain and improves focus. Stimulates abdominal organs. Improves posture and body alignment. Therapeutic for flat feet and sciatica. Strengthens spine.
precautions: Contraindications: High blood pressure (don't fold deeply), back injury, hamstring injury. Keep knees straight but not locked. If hamstrings are tight, keep hands on blocks beside front foot instead of in prayer position. Avoid deep forward fold if you have severe back problems.

title: Virabhadrasana III - Warrior III
info: Warrior III is a challenging balancing pose requiring strength and focus. Stand in Tadasana. Shift weight to right foot. Hinge forward from hips while simultaneously lifting left leg behind you. Extend arms forward or alongside body. Create one straight line from fingertips through torso to left foot - body parallel to floor. Keep hips level and square to floor. Engage standing leg and core strongly. Flex back foot. Gaze down at floor or forward. Hold 30-60 seconds. Return to standing and repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Strengthens entire back body - ankles, legs, shoulders, back. Tones abdomen. Improves balance and posture. Develops concentration and mental focus. Strengthens core muscles. Improves coordination. Therapeutic for improving body awareness and alignment.
precautions: Contraindications: High blood pressure, heart problems, recent abdominal surgery. Practice near a wall or use a chair for support when learning. Those with balance issues should practice with support. Keep neck in neutral - don't strain by looking forward if it causes tension.

title: Malasana - Garland Pose (Yogic Squat)
info: Malasana is a natural resting position in many cultures. Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width, toes turned out. Bend knees and lower hips into a squat. Bring hands to prayer position at heart center. Use elbows to gently press knees open. Lengthen spine and lift chest. Keep heels on floor if possible; if not, place folded blanket under heels. Keep weight in heels. Hold for 1-5 minutes, breathing deeply. This is a resting pose that can be held for extended periods.
benefits: Opens hips, groins, and ankles deeply. Strengthens core and pelvic floor. Aids digestion and elimination. Stretches lower back. Tones abdominal muscles. Prepares body for childbirth. Improves balance and stability. Therapeutic for constipation and flat feet. Grounds and centers energy.
precautions: Contraindications: Knee injury, ankle injury, low back injury. If heels don't reach floor, use support under heels. Those with knee problems should practice cautiously and not go too deep. Pregnant women should keep knees wide apart. Avoid if you have severe knee or hip problems.

title: Baddha Konasana - Butterfly Pose (Bound Angle Pose)
info: Baddha Konasana is excellent for hip opening. Sit with spine erect, legs extended. Bend both knees and bring soles of feet together, drawing heels toward pelvis. Hold feet or ankles with hands. Let knees drop toward floor (don't force). Sit tall, lengthening spine. For deeper stretch, fold forward from hips while maintaining long spine. Can gently pulse knees up and down like butterfly wings for dynamic variation. Hold static position for 1-5 minutes, breathing deeply.
benefits: Opens hips and groin deeply. Stretches inner thighs and knees. Stimulates abdominal organs, ovaries, and prostate. Improves circulation in pelvis. Helps relieve menstrual discomfort and menopause symptoms. Therapeutic for flat feet, high blood pressure, infertility, and sciatica. Prepares body for childbirth. Reduces fatigue. Soothes digestive problems.
precautions: Contraindications: Groin or knee injury, sciatica. If knees are high off floor, place blocks or blankets under knees for support. Don't force knees down. Those with lower back issues should sit on a blanket or block. Avoid deep forward fold if pregnant (keep spine upright).

title: Gomukhasana - Cow Face Pose
info: Gomukhasana resembles a cow's face when viewed from front. Sit with legs extended. Bend left knee and place left foot beside right hip. Cross right leg over left, stacking right knee over left knee, right foot beside left hip. Sit evenly on both sitting bones. Extend right arm up, bend elbow bringing right hand down back. Reach left arm to side, bend elbow bringing left hand up back. Clasp hands behind back if possible; if not, use a strap. Sit tall, lifting chest. Hold 1-3 minutes. Release and repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Opens hips and shoulders deeply. Stretches ankles, thighs, shoulders, armpits, chest, and triceps. Improves posture. Therapeutic for sciatica, frozen shoulder, and chronic knee pain. Stretches hip rotators. Opens chest and improves breathing. Strengthens spine.
precautions: Contraindications: Serious neck, shoulder, knee, or hip injury. If hands don't meet, use a strap between them. If hips are tight, sit on a block or blanket. Those with knee problems should practice leg position carefully or modify. If shoulders are very tight, work on arm position separately.

title: Janu Sirsasana - Head-to-Knee Forward Bend
info: Janu Sirsasana is a calming forward bend. Sit with legs extended. Bend right knee and place sole of right foot against inner left thigh. Right knee drops to side. Square torso to face over extended left leg. Inhale and lengthen spine, raising arms. Exhale and fold forward from hips over left leg, keeping spine long. Hold left foot, ankle, or use strap around foot. With each inhale lengthen, with each exhale fold deeper. Eventually head may rest on shin. Hold 1-3 minutes. Repeat on opposite side.
benefits: Stretches spine, shoulders, hamstrings, and groin. Calms brain and relieves mild depression. Stimulates liver and kidneys. Improves digestion. Relieves anxiety, fatigue, headache, and menstrual discomfort. Therapeutic for high blood pressure, insomnia, and sinusitis. Soothes menopause symptoms.
precautions: Contraindications: Asthma, diarrhea, knee injury. Those with lower back problems should keep spine straight and use props. Don't round spine - fold from hips. If hamstrings are tight, use a strap and keep knee slightly bent. Pregnant women should keep legs wider apart.

title: Upavishta Konasana - Wide-Angle Seated Forward Bend
info: Upavishta Konasana provides an intense inner thigh and hamstring stretch. Sit with legs extended in a wide V-shape, as wide as comfortable. Flex feet, toes pointing up. Place hands on floor in front of torso. Inhale and lengthen spine. Exhale and walk hands forward, folding from hips. Keep spine long as long as possible. Eventually torso may rest on floor between legs. Can also fold over right leg, then center, then left leg. Hold 1-3 minutes, breathing deeply.
benefits: Stretches insides and backs of legs deeply. Opens hips and groin. Stimulates abdominal organs. Strengthens spine. Calms the brain. Releases tension in lower back. Therapeutic for arthritis, sciatica, and infertility. Improves flexibility for other poses.
precautions: Contraindications: Lower back injury, hamstring injury. Sit on a blanket if hips are tight. Don't force the forward fold - let gravity do the work. Keep knees and toes pointing straight up. Those with very tight hamstrings should keep legs closer together. Avoid if you have severe sciatica.

title: Dhanurasana - Bow Pose
info: Dhanurasana resembles an archer's bow. Lie on stomach with feet hip-width apart, arms alongside body. Bend knees bringing heels toward buttocks. Reach back and grasp ankles (outside or inside). Inhale and simultaneously lift chest and kick feet into hands, raising thighs off floor. Lift chest and head. Draw shoulders away from ears. Gaze forward or slightly up. The body curves like a bow. Hold 20-30 seconds, breathing as normally as possible. Exhale and release. Rest in child's pose.
benefits: Stretches entire front body - thighs, abdomen, chest, throat. Strengthens back muscles. Stimulates abdominal organs and improves digestion. Opens chest and improves breathing. Improves posture. Therapeutic for menstrual discomfort, constipation, and respiratory ailments. Stimulates reproductive organs. Reduces stress and fatigue.
precautions: Contraindications: High or low blood pressure, migraine, hernia, neck injury, low back injury, recent abdominal surgery, pregnancy. Don't practice if you have serious back problems. Keep neck in neutral - don't strain it. If difficult to grasp ankles, use a strap around ankles.

title: Matsyasana - Fish Pose
info: Matsyasana is the 'fish pose' said to help one float like a fish. Lie on back with legs extended or in Padmasana (lotus). Place hands palms-down under buttocks. Press forearms and elbows firmly into floor. Inhale and lift chest, arching back and tilting head back. Top of head may rest lightly on floor, but weight should be in elbows, not head. Expand chest fully. Hold 30-60 seconds, breathing deeply. To release, press elbows down, lift head, and slowly lower back to floor.
benefits: Stretches deep hip flexors, intercostals, and abdominal muscles. Opens chest and throat. Stretches and stimulates throat and belly organs. Strengthens upper back and back of neck. Therapeutic for respiratory problems, anxiety, and fatigue. Improves posture. Stimulates thyroid and parathyroid glands. Relieves tension in neck and shoulders.
precautions: Contraindications: High or low blood pressure, migraine, serious neck or lower back injury. Don't place too much weight on head - use elbows for support. Those with neck problems should place a folded blanket under head. Avoid if you have serious spinal problems.

title: Urdhva Dhanurasana - Wheel Pose (Upward Bow)
info: Urdhva Dhanurasana is a deep backbend requiring strength and flexibility. Lie on back, bend knees, place feet hip-width apart near buttocks. Place palms on floor beside ears, fingers pointing toward shoulders. Press firmly into hands and feet. Inhale and lift hips and chest, straightening arms and legs as much as comfortable. Form a high arch with body. Press into all four corners of feet. Engage legs strongly. Relax head and neck. Hold 30-60 seconds. To release, tuck chin and slowly lower down.
benefits: Strengthens arms, wrists, legs, buttocks, abdomen, and spine. Stretches chest, lungs, shoulders, hip flexors, and abdomen. Stimulates thyroid and pituitary glands. Energizes entire body. Therapeutic for asthma, back pain, infertility, and osteoporosis. Builds confidence and courage. Improves mood.
precautions: Contraindications: Back injury, carpal tunnel syndrome, diarrhea, headache, heart problems, high or low blood pressure, pregnancy. This is an advanced pose - build up with bridge pose and other backbends first. Keep feet parallel and knees aligned. Don't practice without proper warm-up. Seek expert guidance when learning.

title: Sirsasana - Headstand (King of Asanas)
info: Sirsasana is called the 'king of asanas' for its benefits. Start on hands and knees. Interlace fingers, place forearms on floor with elbows shoulder-width apart. Place crown of head on floor, back of head cradled by hands. Straighten legs, walk feet toward head. When hips are over shoulders, slowly lift feet off floor, bending knees initially. Straighten legs upward once balanced. Body should be in one straight line. Engage core and legs. Hold 1-5 minutes. To come down, bend knees and slowly lower with control. Rest in child's pose.
benefits: Increases blood flow to brain. Improves concentration, memory, and mental clarity. Strengthens core, arms, and shoulders. Improves balance and body awareness. Stimulates pituitary and pineal glands. Therapeutic for asthma, infertility, insomnia, and sinusitis. Relieves stress and mild depression. Builds confidence.
precautions: Contraindications: Back injury, headache, heart condition, high blood pressure, menstruation, neck injury, pregnancy, glaucoma, detached retina. MUST learn under expert supervision. Practice against wall initially. Don't kick up - use control. Stop if you feel pressure in head or eyes. This is an advanced pose requiring significant preparation.

title: Sarvangasana - Shoulder Stand (Queen of Asanas)
info: Sarvangasana means 'all-limbs pose' and is called the 'queen of asanas.' Use folded blankets under shoulders for neck protection. Lie on back. Bend knees, press arms down, and lift legs overhead. Support back with hands, elbows close together. Extend legs straight up toward ceiling. Body should form a straight line from shoulders to toes. Chin naturally presses into chest (Jalandhara Bandha). Weight is on shoulders and upper arms, never on neck. Hold 1-5 minutes. To release, bend knees, slowly roll down vertebra by vertebra.
benefits: Improves circulation throughout body. Stimulates thyroid and parathyroid glands. Regulates metabolism. Calms nervous system. Reduces stress and fatigue. Therapeutic for asthma, infertility, and sinusitis. Relieves menopause symptoms. Improves digestion. Strengthens shoulders and core. Helps with varicose veins.
precautions: Contraindications: Diarrhea, headache, high blood pressure, menstruation, neck injury, pregnancy (if not practiced before pregnancy), glaucoma, detached retina. ALWAYS use blankets to protect neck. Never turn head while in pose. Those with neck problems should avoid or practice with expert guidance. Don't practice if you have serious spinal problems.

title: Halasana - Plow Pose
info: Halasana is often practiced after shoulder stand. From shoulder stand or lying on back, support lower back with hands. Slowly lower legs over head until toes touch floor behind head. Keep legs straight. Arms can extend on floor opposite to legs, palms down, or remain supporting back. Legs and torso should form a 90-degree angle if possible. Breathe normally. Hold 1-3 minutes. To release, support back with hands and slowly roll down.
benefits: Calms the brain and nervous system. Reduces stress and fatigue. Stimulates abdominal organs and thyroid. Stretches shoulders and spine. Therapeutic for backache, headache, infertility, insomnia, and sinusitis. Helps relieve menopause symptoms. Relieves digestive problems.
precautions: Contraindications: Diarrhea, menstruation, neck injury, asthma, high blood pressure, pregnancy. Use blankets under shoulders to protect neck. Don't force toes to floor - use a chair or blocks for support if needed. Never turn head while in pose. Those with stiff backs should practice with feet on a chair behind head.

title: Bakasana - Crow Pose (Crane Pose)
info: Bakasana is a foundational arm balance building strength and confidence. Squat with feet together. Place hands on floor shoulder-width apart, fingers spread wide. Bend elbows slightly, creating a shelf. Place knees high on backs of upper arms (on triceps). Shift weight forward onto hands. Look forward, not down. Slowly lift one foot, then the other off floor. Bring feet together. Straighten arms as strength develops. Hold 20-60 seconds. To release, slowly lower feet to floor.
benefits: Strengthens arms, wrists, and core. Tones abdominal organs. Opens groins. Improves balance and concentration. Builds confidence. Prepares for more advanced arm balances. Strengthens hip flexors. Develops body awareness and control.
precautions: Contraindications: Carpal tunnel syndrome, wrist injury, shoulder injury, pregnancy. Place a pillow or blanket in front of you when learning in case you fall forward. Keep elbows close together. Don't practice if you have serious wrist problems. Build wrist strength gradually.

title: Chaturanga Dandasana - Four-Limbed Staff Pose
info: Chaturanga is a key transition pose in Vinyasa yoga, like a yoga push-up. From plank position with hands shoulder-width apart, shift weight slightly forward onto toes. Exhale and lower body in one straight line until upper arms are parallel to floor, elbows at 90 degrees. Elbows stay close to ribs, pointing back. Core engaged strongly. Body hovers a few inches above floor. Shoulders stay level with elbows. Hold 10-30 seconds or use as transition. To release, lower to floor or press back to plank.
benefits: Strengthens arms, wrists, shoulders, and core. Tones abdomen. Builds upper body and core strength. Improves posture. Prepares body for more advanced arm balances. Develops mental focus and determination. Strengthens muscles around spine.
precautions: Contraindications: Carpal tunnel syndrome, wrist or shoulder injury, pregnancy (later stages). Keep elbows at 90 degrees - don't let them splay out or shoulders drop below elbows. Modify by lowering knees to floor. Build strength gradually. Common mistakes: sagging hips, shoulders dropping too low, elbows wide.

title: Vasisthasana - Side Plank Pose
info: Vasisthasana is named after sage Vasistha. From plank, shift weight to right hand and outer edge of right foot. Stack left foot on right. Rotate torso to left, extending left arm straight up toward ceiling. Left arm, torso, and right arm form one straight line. Stack hips and shoulders. Gaze at left hand or forward. Engage entire body. Hold 30-60 seconds. Return to plank and repeat on opposite side. Modifications: lower knee of bottom leg to floor, or place top foot in front of bottom foot.
benefits: Strengthens arms, wrists, legs, and core. Improves balance and concentration. Tones entire body. Strengthens obliques. Opens chest. Improves focus and determination. Builds stamina. Therapeutic for strengthening wrists.
precautions: Contraindications: Serious wrist, elbow, or shoulder injury. Those with wrist problems should practice forearm variation. Keep supporting hand directly under shoulder. Engage core to avoid sagging hips. Modify as needed.

title: Chandra Namaskar - Moon Salutation
info: Chandra Namaskar is a cooling, calming sequence honoring the moon. The sequence: 1) Prayer Pose (standing), 2) Arms overhead with side bend right, 3) Return center, side bend left, 4) Forward Fold, 5) Low Lunge right leg back, 6) Low Squat, 7) Low Lunge left leg back, 8) Forward Fold, 9) Arms overhead with side bend right, 10) Center, side bend left, 11) Prayer Pose. Flow smoothly between poses, coordinating breath. Emphasize lateral movements and hip openers. Practice in evening or when you need calming energy.
benefits: Calms nervous system and mind. Cools the body. Relieves stress and anxiety. Opens hips and side body. Improves flexibility. Balances energy. Prepares for sleep. Complements active Yang practices. Therapeutic for insomnia and hyperactivity.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Move slowly and mindfully. Respect your body's limits. This is generally safe for all levels. Those with knee problems should modify the low squat.

title: Morning Energizing Sequence - 15 Minutes
info: A quick morning practice to energize. 1) Child's Pose - 1 min, 2) Cat-Cow - 1 min, 3) Downward Dog - 1 min, 4) Sun Salutations - 3 rounds (6 min), 5) Warrior I & II - 1 min each side (2 min), 6) Tree Pose - 30 sec each side (1 min), 7) Seated Forward Bend - 1 min, 8) Seated Twist both sides - 1 min total, 9) Savasana - 1 min. Focus on linking breath with movement. Move dynamically to build heat and energy.
benefits: Energizes body and mind for the day. Improves circulation. Wakes up all body systems. Builds strength and flexibility. Improves focus. Sets positive intention for day. Takes minimal time but provides maximum benefit.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Listen to your body - don't force. Modify poses as needed. Skip or modify if you have any injuries.

title: Evening Wind-Down Sequence - 20 Minutes
info: Calming sequence for evening relaxation. 1) Easy Pose with gentle neck rolls - 2 min, 2) Cat-Cow - 2 min slow, 3) Child's Pose - 2 min, 4) Gentle Seated Forward Bend - 3 min, 5) Supine Twist both sides - 2 min each (4 min), 6) Happy Baby - 2 min, 7) Legs-up-the-Wall - 3 min, 8) Savasana - 5 min. Practice slowly and gently. Focus on releasing tension. Use props for comfort.
benefits: Calms nervous system. Prepares for restful sleep. Releases physical and mental tension. Reduces stress and anxiety. Improves sleep quality. Activates parasympathetic nervous system. Soothes digestive system.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. This is very gentle and safe. Avoid if you have serious injuries. Use props liberally for maximum comfort and relaxation.

title: Desk Yoga Sequence - 10 Minutes
info: Sequence to counteract sitting at desk. Can be done in office clothes, no mat needed. 1) Seated neck rolls - 1 min, 2) Shoulder rolls and shrugs - 1 min, 3) Seated spinal twist both sides - 1 min each, 4) Seated cat-cow (hands on knees) - 1 min, 5) Wrist circles and stretches - 1 min, 6) Standing forward fold - 1 min, 7) Standing side bend each side - 30 sec each, 8) Chair pose - 30 sec, 9) Tree pose - 30 sec each side, 10) Seated meditation/breathing - 1 min.
benefits: Relieves tension from sitting. Counteracts poor posture. Reduces back and neck pain. Improves circulation. Boosts energy and focus. Reduces eye strain. Releases hip flexors. Improves mood and productivity.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Very safe for office environment. Move gently. Don't force. Breathe naturally.

title: Flexibility Flow - 30 Minutes
info: Sequence focused on increasing flexibility. Hold poses longer (2-3 minutes each). 1) Butterfly Pose - 3 min, 2) Wide-Angle Seated Forward Fold - 3 min, 3) Pigeon Pose - 3 min each side (6 min total), 4) Seated Forward Bend - 3 min, 5) Reclined Hand-to-Big-Toe (both variations) - 2 min each side (8 min total), 6) Supine Twist - 2 min each side (4 min), 7) Savasana - 3 min. Use props. Breathe into stretches. Release with each exhale.
benefits: Significantly improves flexibility. Releases deep tension in connective tissue. Calms nervous system. Improves range of motion. Therapeutic for tight hips and hamstrings. Prepares body for deeper poses. Meditative and introspective.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Never force stretches. Use props liberally. Those with very tight muscles should hold for shorter duration initially. Avoid if you have joint hypermobility. Be patient - flexibility develops gradually.

title: Strength Building Flow - 40 Minutes
info: Sequence to build strength and stamina. 1) Warm-up: Sun Salutations - 5 rounds (10 min), 2) Warrior sequence: Warrior I, II, III, Side Angle - 2 min each pose, both sides (16 min total), 3) Core work: Plank, Dolphin Plank, Side Plank variations - 1 min each (3 min), 4) Chair Pose - 1 min, 5) Crow Pose practice - 2 min, 6) Boat Pose - 1 min, 7) Locust Pose - 1 min, 8) Bow Pose - 1 min, 9) Cool-down: Child's Pose, Seated Forward Bend - 2 min each, 10) Savasana - 3 min.
benefits: Builds full-body strength. Increases stamina and endurance. Tones muscles. Burns calories. Improves cardiovascular health. Builds bone density. Boosts metabolism. Increases mental toughness and focus.
precautions: Contraindications: Heart conditions, uncontrolled high blood pressure, recent surgery. Warm up properly. Stay hydrated. Don't hold breath - breathe steadily. Modify as needed. Those new to yoga should start with gentler practice.

title: Muladhara Chakra - Root Chakra
info: Muladhara is the first chakra, located at the base of the spine/perineum. Element: Earth. Color: Red. Seed mantra: LAM. Represents: Survival, grounding, stability, security, basic needs. Physical associations: Legs, feet, bones, large intestine, adrenal glands. When balanced: Feeling grounded, safe, secure, stable. Strong foundation. Good physical health. Financial security. When imbalanced: Fear, anxiety, insecurity. Financial problems. Eating disorders. Low back pain. Constipation. To balance: Grounding poses (Mountain, Warrior, Tree), walking barefoot, connecting with nature, red foods, affirmations like 'I am safe and grounded.'
benefits: Understanding root chakra helps address issues of security and grounding. Balancing practices create stability in life. Supports healthy relationship with physical body and material world.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Approach with open mind but also discernment.

title: Svadhisthana Chakra - Sacral Chakra
info: Svadhisthana is the second chakra, located in lower abdomen/sacrum area. Element: Water. Color: Orange. Seed mantra: VAM. Represents: Creativity, sexuality, emotions, pleasure, relationships. Physical associations: Reproductive organs, kidneys, bladder, hip area. When balanced: Comfortable with sexuality. Creative expression flows. Healthy emotions. Passionate about life. When imbalanced: Emotional instability. Sexual dysfunction. Creative blocks. Guilt. Addiction. To balance: Hip openers (Pigeon, Butterfly, Goddess Pose), creative activities, water activities, orange foods, sacral breathing, affirmations like 'I embrace pleasure and abundance.'
benefits: Balancing sacral chakra enhances creativity and emotional intelligence. Supports healthy relationships and sensuality. Promotes joy and passion for life.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Emotional releases may occur during practice.

title: Manipura Chakra - Solar Plexus Chakra
info: Manipura is the third chakra, located at solar plexus/navel area. Element: Fire. Color: Yellow. Seed mantra: RAM. Represents: Personal power, will, confidence, self-esteem, transformation. Physical associations: Digestive system, liver, pancreas, stomach, small intestine. When balanced: Strong self-esteem. Confident. Good boundaries. Strong digestion. Able to manifest goals. When imbalanced: Low self-esteem. Lack of will. Digestive issues. Control issues. Anger. Powerlessness. To balance: Core strengthening poses (Boat, Plank, Warrior III), Kapalabhati pranayama, sun exposure, yellow foods, fire gazing, affirmations like 'I am powerful and confident.'
benefits: Balancing solar plexus chakra builds confidence and personal power. Improves digestion. Supports ability to take action and manifest goals.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Those with digestive issues should also seek medical advice.

title: Anahata Chakra - Heart Chakra
info: Anahata is the fourth chakra, located at the heart center. Element: Air. Color: Green or pink. Seed mantra: YAM. Represents: Love, compassion, forgiveness, relationships, connection. Physical associations: Heart, lungs, circulatory system, arms, hands, thymus gland. When balanced: Loving. Compassionate. Forgiving. Healthy relationships. Self-love. When imbalanced: Difficulty with relationships. Closed-hearted. Jealousy. Loneliness. Heart or lung problems. To balance: Heart openers (Cobra, Camel, Bridge, Wheel), pranayama, loving-kindness meditation, green foods, spending time in nature, affirmations like 'I give and receive love freely.'
benefits: Balancing heart chakra opens capacity for love and compassion. Heals relationship wounds. Improves respiratory and cardiovascular health.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Heart opening can bring up buried emotions.

title: Vishuddha Chakra - Throat Chakra
info: Vishuddha is the fifth chakra, located at the throat. Element: Ether/Space. Color: Blue. Seed mantra: HAM. Represents: Communication, self-expression, truth, authenticity. Physical associations: Throat, thyroid, parathyroid, neck, jaw, mouth, teeth. When balanced: Clear communication. Speaks truth. Good listener. Authentic expression. When imbalanced: Difficulty expressing oneself. Lying. Gossip. Fear of speaking. Thyroid problems. Sore throat. To balance: Shoulder stand, plow pose, fish pose, Ujjayi breathing, chanting, singing, blue foods, journaling, affirmations like 'I speak my truth clearly.'
benefits: Balancing throat chakra improves communication skills. Supports authentic self-expression. May help thyroid function.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Those with thyroid issues should work with healthcare provider.

title: Ajna Chakra - Third Eye Chakra
info: Ajna is the sixth chakra, located between eyebrows. Element: Light. Color: Indigo/purple. Seed mantra: OM. Represents: Intuition, wisdom, imagination, clarity, insight. Physical associations: Brain, eyes, pituitary gland, pineal gland. When balanced: Clear intuition. Good imagination. Wisdom. Clear thinking. When imbalanced: Lack of clarity. Confusion. Delusion. Headaches. Eye problems. Nightmares. To balance: Child's pose, forward folds, meditation, visualization, dream work, purple foods, limiting screen time, affirmations like 'I trust my intuition.'
benefits: Balancing third eye chakra enhances intuition and mental clarity. Improves imagination and insight. Supports spiritual development.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Intense third eye work should be done gradually.

title: Sahasrara Chakra - Crown Chakra
info: Sahasrara is the seventh chakra, located at crown of head. Element: Thought/Consciousness. Color: Violet or white. Seed mantra: AUM or silence. Represents: Spiritual connection, enlightenment, unity, pure consciousness. Physical associations: Cerebral cortex, pineal gland, central nervous system. When balanced: Spiritual connection. Sense of peace. Wisdom. Unity consciousness. When imbalanced: Disconnection from spirituality. Closed-mindedness. Cynicism. Learning difficulties. To balance: Headstand, meditation, pranayama, prayer, fasting, silence, study of spiritual texts, affirmations like 'I am connected to divine consciousness.'
benefits: Balancing crown chakra facilitates spiritual awakening. Creates sense of unity and peace. Supports highest states of consciousness.
precautions: Chakra work is complementary to, not replacement for, medical or psychological care. Crown chakra work should be grounded in lower chakra stability.

title: Yoga for Weight Management
info: Yoga supports healthy weight through multiple pathways. Recommended practices: Active vinyasa flows build cardiovascular fitness. Strength-building poses increase muscle mass and metabolism. Core work (Boat, Plank variations) tones abdominal area. Power yoga and Ashtanga styles burn calories. Pranayama increases oxygen delivery and metabolic efficiency. Meditation reduces stress eating and emotional eating. Mindfulness practices improve relationship with food. Consistent practice regulates hormones affecting weight. Key principles: Practice 5-6 days per week mixing active and restorative styles. Combine with healthy diet and adequate sleep. Address underlying stress and emotional issues.
